docs.title: Presentation
docs.text:
After starting my Python learning journey and being a senior technical writer, API documentation initially seemed like the next step. At first, I dreamt of it as a distant and mysterious land, far off. Now, it has become an exciting and achievable area of knowledge and practice.

This repository showcases my approach to learning the fundamentals and nuances of API documentation. You'll find various resources, examples, and my personal insights as I explore best practices in documenting APIs.

I¡ll be coding in Python and following the API first approach suggested by the OpenAPI specificiation.

I hope this helps you learn about API documentation!

docs.title: Goals
docs.text: This repository has two main goals. First, to present the complete process of API development from ideation, development, documentation, and release from the point of view of a technical writer. Second, to show and explain the Python API code to gain a better understanding of API development and the work of our fellow developers.

docs.title: Process
docs.text:
To achieve the goal of learning about API documentation (and coding), I'll follow a progressive and iterative approach, which consists of the following steps:

  1. Disclose and describe the steps of the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC).
  2. Create all required SDLC documentation.
  3. Create a kanban-like board using GitHub projects.
  4. Implement the user stories from the GitHub project iteratively.
  5. Create the Python code and the OpenAPI Specification.
  6. Explain API testing using Swagger and Postman.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The software is delivered to the production environment, and it is made available to end-users. Technical Writing Role: Writers assist in creating deployment guides and documenting configuration settings, upgrade paths, and rollback procedures.

docs.title: Associated Documents: Deployment Guide
docs.text: Deployment Guide: Instructions on how to install, configure, and deploy the software to the production environment.

docs.title: Example
docs.text: A Cloud Deployment Manual for installing the application on AWS, covering steps for server setup, load balancing, and environment configuration.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
As part of the rollout, end-users are trained on the new system through tutorials or training sessions. Technical Writing Role: Writers create user guides, FAQs, video tutorials, and other materials to facilitate learning.

T

docs.title: Associated Documents: User Manual:
docs.text: Guides users on how to operate the system.

docs.title: Example
docs.text: A Getting Started Guide for an e-commerce platform that explains how users can create accounts, browse products, and complete purchases.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The actual development of the software takes place. Developers write code, build features, and conduct initial unit testing. Technical Writing Role: Writers create developer-focused documentation, such as API references or code integration guides, and collaborate on in-line code comments.

T

docs.title: Associated Documents: API Documentation
docs.text: Details how to use and integrate with the system’s APIs.

docs.title: Example
docs.text: A REST API Guide for integrating an external payment service with your system, detailing endpoints, request/response formats, and authentication.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
After deployment, the system is monitored, and any issues are addressed with patches or updates. New features may be added in future iterations. Technical Writing Role: Writers help with user guides, troubleshooting documentation, and release notes for future versions.

T

docs.title: Associated Documents: Release Notes
docs.text: Summarize new features, bug fixes, and known issues for each new version.

docs.title: Example
docs.text: A Release Notes document for version 1.2.0, listing new features, fixed bugs, and deprecated functions.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: In this phase, the project's goals, objectives, scope, and potential risks are identified. Stakeholders and teams gather functional and non-functional requirements for the system. Technical Writing Role: Technical writers collaborate with stakeholders, engineers, and product owners to document the business requirements, technical specifications, and scope of work.

docs.title: Associated Documents: Requirements Specification Document
docs.text: Requirements Specification Document (RSD): This outlines the system's functional and non-functional requirements.

docs.title: Example
docs.text: A Business Requirements Document (BRD) that details what the end-users expect from the system.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Based on the requirements, architects and developers create high-level and detailed designs of the system. This includes the architecture, database design, and user interface mockups. Technical Writing Role: Writers document the design specifications and data models to ensure developers and stakeholders have clear guidance on implementation.

docs.title: Associated Documents: Deployment Guide
docs.text: System Design Document (SDD): Describes system components, interfaces, data models, and architectural diagrams.

docs.title: Example
docs.text: A Data Flow Diagram (DFD) explaining how data moves within the system and a System Architecture Document that describes server infrastructure and client-server communication.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The system undergoes various forms of testing, such as unit, integration, system, and acceptance testing, to identify bugs and ensure all requirements are met. Technical Writing Role: Writers help create testing plans and document known issues or test results.

T

docs.title: Associated Documents: Test Case Document
docs.text: Test Case Document: Defines how to verify that each function or feature meets the requirements.

docs.title: Example
docs.text: A Test Plan for ensuring that the user authentication feature works correctly, detailing the different test cases, expected outcomes, and pass/fail criteria.
